config.text: When should you update your vehicle registration certificate?

choices.label: When you pass your driving test
When you move house
When your vehicle needs an MOT
When you have a collision

correct.text: As the registered keeper of a vehicle, it's up to you to inform DVLA of any changes in your details; for example, your name or address. You do this by completing and sending off the relevant section of the registration certificate.

incorrect.text: As the registered keeper of a vehicle, it's up to you to inform DVLA of any changes in your details; for example, your name or address. You do this by completing and sending off the relevant section of the registration certificate.

config.text: When must your vehicle have valid insurance cover?

choices.label: Before you can make a SORN
Before you can sell the vehicle
Before you can scrap the vehicle
Before you can tax the vehicle

correct.text: Your vehicle must have valid insurance cover before you can tax it. If required, it will also need to have a valid MOT certificate. You can tax your vehicle online, by phone or at certain post offices.

incorrect.text: Your vehicle must have valid insurance cover before you can tax it. If required, it will also need to have a valid MOT certificate. You can tax your vehicle online, by phone or at certain post offices.

config.text: What must you check before you drive someone else's vehicle?

choices.label: That the vehicle owner has third-party insurance cover
That your own vehicle has insurance cover
That the vehicle is insured for your use
That the insurance documents are in the vehicle

correct.text: Driving a vehicle without insurance cover is illegal, so be sure that, whoever's car you drive, you're insured – whether on their policy or on your own. If you need to take out insurance, it's worth comparing several quotes before you decide which insurance provider best meets your needs.

incorrect.text: Driving a vehicle without insurance cover is illegal, so be sure that, whoever's car you drive, you're insured – whether on their policy or on your own. If you need to take out insurance, it's worth comparing several quotes before you decide which insurance provider best meets your needs.

config.text: Who's legally responsible for ensuring that a vehicle registration certificate (V5C) is updated?

choices.label: The registered vehicle keeper
The vehicle manufacturer
Your insurance company
The licensing authority

correct.text: It's your legal responsibility to keep the details on your vehicle registration certificate (V5C) up to date. You should tell the licensing authority about any changes. These include your name, address or vehicle details. If you don't do this, you may have problems when you try to sell your vehicle.

incorrect.text: It's your legal responsibility to keep the details on your vehicle registration certificate (V5C) up to date. You should tell the licensing authority about any changes. These include your name, address or vehicle details. If you don't do this, you may have problems when you try to sell your vehicle.

config.text: What does it mean if your insurance policy has an excess of £500?

choices.label: The insurance company will pay the first £500 of any claim
You'll be paid £500 if you don't claim within one year
Your vehicle is insured for a value of £500 if it's stolen
You'll have to pay the first £500 of the cost of any claim

correct.text: Having an excess on your policy will help to keep the premium down. However, if you make a claim, you'll have to pay the excess yourself – in this case, £500.

incorrect.text: Having an excess on your policy will help to keep the premium down. However, if you make a claim, you'll have to pay the excess yourself – in this case, £500.

config.text: What's a Statutory Off-Road Notification (SORN)?

choices.label: A notification to tell DVSA that a vehicle doesn't have a current MOT
Information kept by the police about the owner of a vehicle
A notification to tell DVLA that a vehicle isn't being used on the road
Information held by insurance companies to check a vehicle is insured

correct.text: If you want to keep a vehicle untaxed and off the public road, you must make a SORN. It's an offence not to do so. Your SORN is valid until your vehicle is taxed, sold or scrapped.

incorrect.text: If you want to keep a vehicle untaxed and off the public road, you must make a SORN. It's an offence not to do so. Your SORN is valid until your vehicle is taxed, sold or scrapped.

config.text: Your insurer will issue you with an insurance certificate. When must you produce this document for inspection?

choices.label: When making a SORN
When buying or selling a vehicle
When a police officer asks you for it
When your vehicle is having an MOT test

correct.text: You must produce a valid insurance certificate when requested by a police officer. If you can't do this immediately, you may be asked to take it to a police station. Other documents you may be asked to produce are your driving licence and the vehicle's MOT certificate.

incorrect.text: You must produce a valid insurance certificate when requested by a police officer. If you can't do this immediately, you may be asked to take it to a police station. Other documents you may be asked to produce are your driving licence and the vehicle's MOT certificate.

config.text: What's the maximum fine for driving or riding without insurance?

choices.label: Unlimited

correct.text: Driving or riding without insurance is a serious offence. As well as an unlimited fine, you may be disqualified or incur penalty points.

incorrect.text: Driving or riding without insurance is a serious offence. As well as an unlimited fine, you may be disqualified or incur penalty points.

config.text: What does third-party insurance cover?

choices.label: Damage to your vehicle
Damage to other vehicles
Injury to yourself
All damage and injury

correct.text: Third-party insurance cover is usually cheaper than comprehensive cover. However, it doesn't cover any damage caused to your own vehicle or property. It only covers damage and injury you cause to others.

incorrect.text: Third-party insurance cover is usually cheaper than comprehensive cover. However, it doesn't cover any damage caused to your own vehicle or property. It only covers damage and injury you cause to others.

config.text: For how long is an MOT certificate normally valid?

choices.label: Three years after the date it was issued
10,000 miles
One year after the date it was issued
30,000 miles

correct.text: Some garages will remind you that your vehicle is due for its annual MOT test, but not all do. To ensure continuous cover, you may take your vehicle for its MOT up to one month before its existing MOT certificate expires. The expiry date on the new certificate will be 12 months after the expiry date on the old certificate.

incorrect.text: Some garages will remind you that your vehicle is due for its annual MOT test, but not all do. To ensure continuous cover, you may take your vehicle for its MOT up to one month before its existing MOT certificate expires. The expiry date on the new certificate will be 12 months after the expiry date on the old certificate.

config.text: What must you have when you apply to renew your vehicle tax?

choices.label: Valid insurance
The vehicle's chassis number
The handbook
A valid driving licence

correct.text: You can renew your vehicle tax online, at post offices and by phone using the DVLA vehicle tax service. When applying, make sure you have all the relevant valid documents, including a valid MOT test certificate where applicable.

incorrect.text: You can renew your vehicle tax online, at post offices and by phone using the DVLA vehicle tax service. When applying, make sure you have all the relevant valid documents, including a valid MOT test certificate where applicable.

config.text: What legal requirement must be met by a newly qualified driver?

choices.label: They must display green L plates
They must have a new photograph taken for their full licence
They must be accompanied on their first motorway journey
They must have valid motor insurance

correct.text: It's your responsibility to make sure you're properly insured for the vehicle you're driving. This is the case regardless of whether you're a newly qualified driver or one with more experience.

incorrect.text: It's your responsibility to make sure you're properly insured for the vehicle you're driving. This is the case regardless of whether you're a newly qualified driver or one with more experience.

config.text: In order to supervise a learner driver you need to have held a full driving licence for the same category of vehicle, for at least three years. What other requirement must you meet?

choices.label: To have a car with dual controls
To be at least 21 years old
To be an approved driving instructor
To hold an advanced driving certificate

correct.text: Learner drivers benefit by combining professional driving lessons with private practice. However, you need to be at least 21 years old and have held your driving licence for at least 3 years before you can supervise a learner driver.

incorrect.text: Learner drivers benefit by combining professional driving lessons with private practice. However, you need to be at least 21 years old and have held your driving licence for at least 3 years before you can supervise a learner driver.

config.text: For how long is a Statutory Off-Road Notification (SORN) valid?

choices.label: Until the vehicle is taxed, sold or scrapped
Until the vehicle is insured and MOT'd
Until the vehicle is repaired or modified
Until the vehicle is used on the road

correct.text: A SORN allows you to keep a vehicle off-road and untaxed. SORN will end when the vehicle is taxed, sold or scrapped.

incorrect.text: A SORN allows you to keep a vehicle off-road and untaxed. SORN will end when the vehicle is taxed, sold or scrapped.

config.text: Your car requires an MOT certificate. When is it legal to drive it without an MOT certificate?

choices.label: Up to seven days after the old certificate has run out
When driving to an MOT centre to arrange an appointment
When driving the car with the owner's permission
When driving to an appointment at an MOT centre

correct.text:
When a car is three years old (four years old in Northern Ireland), it must pass an MOT test and have a valid MOT certificate before it can be used on the road. Exceptionally, you may
  • drive to a pre-arranged test appointment or to a garage for repairs required for the test
  • drive vehicles that are more than 40 years old without an MOT test, but they must be in a roadworthy condition before being used on the road. See GOV.UK for more details.

incorrect.text:
When a car is three years old (four years old in Northern Ireland), it must pass an MOT test and have a valid MOT certificate before it can be used on the road. Exceptionally, you may
  • drive to a pre-arranged test appointment or to a garage for repairs required for the test
  • drive vehicles that are more than 40 years old without an MOT test, but they must be in a roadworthy condition before being used on the road. See GOV.UK for more details.

config.text: When could the cost of your insurance be reduced?

choices.label: When you're under 25 years old
When you don't wear glasses
When you pass the driving test first time
When you complete the Pass Plus scheme

correct.text:
The cost of insurance varies with your age and how long you've been driving. Usually, the younger you are, the more expensive it is, especially if you're under 25.
Pass Plus provides additional training to newly qualified drivers. The scheme is recognised by many insurance companies, and taking this extra training could give you reduced insurance premiums, as well as improving your skills and experience.

incorrect.text:
The cost of insurance varies with your age and how long you've been driving. Usually, the younger you are, the more expensive it is, especially if you're under 25.
Pass Plus provides additional training to newly qualified drivers. The scheme is recognised by many insurance companies, and taking this extra training could give you reduced insurance premiums, as well as improving your skills and experience.

config.text: What's a cover note?

choices.label: A document issued before you receive your driving licence
A document issued before you receive your insurance certificate
A document issued before you receive your registration document
A document issued before you receive your MOT certificate

correct.text: Sometimes an insurance company will issue a temporary insurance certificate called a cover note. It gives you the same insurance cover as your certificate but lasts for a limited period, usually one month.

incorrect.text: Sometimes an insurance company will issue a temporary insurance certificate called a cover note. It gives you the same insurance cover as your certificate but lasts for a limited period, usually one month.

config.text: What's the legal minimum insurance cover you must have to drive on public roads?

choices.label: Third party, fire and theft
Comprehensive
Third party only
Personal injury cover

correct.text: The minimum insurance required by law is third-party cover. This covers your liability to others involved in a collision but not damage to your vehicle. Basic third-party insurance also won't cover theft or fire damage. Ask your insurance company for advice on the best cover for you and make sure that you read the policy carefully.

incorrect.text: The minimum insurance required by law is third-party cover. This covers your liability to others involved in a collision but not damage to your vehicle. Basic third-party insurance also won't cover theft or fire damage. Ask your insurance company for advice on the best cover for you and make sure that you read the policy carefully.

config.text: What information is found on a vehicle registration document?

choices.label: The registered keeper
The type of insurance cover
The service history details
The date of the MOT

correct.text: Every vehicle used on the road has a registration document. This shows the vehicle's details, including date of first registration, registration number, registered keeper, previous keeper, make of vehicle, engine size, chassis number, year of manufacture and colour.

incorrect.text: Every vehicle used on the road has a registration document. This shows the vehicle's details, including date of first registration, registration number, registered keeper, previous keeper, make of vehicle, engine size, chassis number, year of manufacture and colour.

config.text: Who's responsible for paying the vehicle tax?

choices.label: The driver of the vehicle
The registered keeper of the vehicle
The car dealer
The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA)

correct.text: The registered keeper of the vehicle is responsible for paying the vehicle tax or making a Statutory Off-Road Notification (SORN) if the vehicle is to be kept untaxed and off the road.

incorrect.text: The registered keeper of the vehicle is responsible for paying the vehicle tax or making a Statutory Off-Road Notification (SORN) if the vehicle is to be kept untaxed and off the road.

config.text: When will a new car need its first MOT test?

choices.label: When it's one year old
When it's three years old
When it's five years old
When it's seven years old

correct.text: The vehicle you drive must be roadworthy and in good condition. If it's over three years old, it must pass an MOT test to remain in use on the road (unless it's exempt from the MOT test – see GOV.UK).

incorrect.text: The vehicle you drive must be roadworthy and in good condition. If it's over three years old, it must pass an MOT test to remain in use on the road (unless it's exempt from the MOT test – see GOV.UK).

config.text: What circumstances require you to notify the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA)?

choices.label: When your health affects your driving
When you have to work abroad
When you lend your vehicle to someone
When your vehicle needs an MOT certificate

correct.text: DVLA holds the records of all vehicles, drivers and riders in Great Britain and Northern Ireland. They need to know if you have a medical condition that might affect your ability to drive safely. You must tell them if your health deteriorates and you become unfit to drive.

incorrect.text: DVLA holds the records of all vehicles, drivers and riders in Great Britain and Northern Ireland. They need to know if you have a medical condition that might affect your ability to drive safely. You must tell them if your health deteriorates and you become unfit to drive.

config.text: You've just passed your first practical driving test. What will you have to do if you get six penalty points on your licence in the next two years?

choices.label: Retake only your theory test
Retake your theory and practical tests
Retake only your practical test
Reapply for your full licence immediately

correct.text: If you accumulate six or more penalty points within two years of gaining your first full licence, it will be revoked. The six or more points include any gained due to offences you committed before passing your test. If this happens, you may only drive as a learner until you pass both the theory and practical tests again.

incorrect.text: If you accumulate six or more penalty points within two years of gaining your first full licence, it will be revoked. The six or more points include any gained due to offences you committed before passing your test. If this happens, you may only drive as a learner until you pass both the theory and practical tests again.

config.text: What's covered by third-party insurance?

choices.label: Damage to your vehicle
Fire damage to your vehicle
Flood damage to your vehicle
Damage to other vehicles

correct.text: Third-party insurance doesn't cover damage to your own vehicle or injury to yourself. If you have a crash and your vehicle is damaged, you might have to carry out the repairs at your own expense.

incorrect.text: Third-party insurance doesn't cover damage to your own vehicle or injury to yourself. If you have a crash and your vehicle is damaged, you might have to carry out the repairs at your own expense.

config.text: Your car needs to pass an MOT test. What may be invalidated if you drive the car without a current MOT certificate?

choices.label: The vehicle service record
The vehicle insurance
The vehicle tax
The vehicle registration document

correct.text: If your vehicle requires an MOT certificate, it's illegal to drive it without one and your insurance may be invalid if you do so. The only exceptions are that you may drive to a pre-arranged MOT test appointment, or to a garage for repairs required for the test.

incorrect.text: If your vehicle requires an MOT certificate, it's illegal to drive it without one and your insurance may be invalid if you do so. The only exceptions are that you may drive to a pre-arranged MOT test appointment, or to a garage for repairs required for the test.

meta.xref: DES s2, HC p140, HC p142

config.text: When must you contact the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA)?

choices.label: When you get a parking ticket
When you change your vehicle
When you use your vehicle for work
When your vehicle's insurance is due

correct.text: DVLA needs to keep its records up to date. It sends out a reminder when a vehicle's tax is due for renewal. To do this, it needs to know the name and address of the registered keeper. Every vehicle in the country is registered, so it's possible to trace its history.

incorrect.text: DVLA needs to keep its records up to date. It sends out a reminder when a vehicle's tax is due for renewal. To do this, it needs to know the name and address of the registered keeper. Every vehicle in the country is registered, so it's possible to trace its history.

config.text: A police officer asks to see your documents. You don't have them with you. How many days do you have to produce them at a police station?

choices.label: 5 days
7 days
14 days
21 days

correct.text: You don't have to carry your vehicle's documents wherever you go. If a police officer asks to see them and you don't have them with you, you may be asked to produce them at a police station within 7 days.

incorrect.text: You don't have to carry your vehicle's documents wherever you go. If a police officer asks to see them and you don't have them with you, you may be asked to produce them at a police station within 7 days.

config.text: What do you need before you can legally use a motor vehicle on the road?

choices.label: An appropriate driving licence
Breakdown cover
Proof of your identity
A vehicle handbook

correct.text:
Using a motor vehicle on the road illegally carries a heavy fine and can lead to penalty points on your driving licence. You must
  • hold a valid driving licence for the class of vehicle you're using
  • be insured to drive the vehicle.
If required, the vehicle must have a current MOT test certificate and be taxed for use on the road.

incorrect.text:
Using a motor vehicle on the road illegally carries a heavy fine and can lead to penalty points on your driving licence. You must
  • hold a valid driving licence for the class of vehicle you're using
  • be insured to drive the vehicle.
If required, the vehicle must have a current MOT test certificate and be taxed for use on the road.
